Expectation1: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation1: A monthly food drive for the local homeless shelter is scheduled to take place at the convent today.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: Today was the day of our monthly food drive at the convent, and as a nun, I knew how much the sisters and the people at the shelter depended on my help. The kitchen was already bustling when I slipped out to cast my ballot, determined to fulfill my civic duty before returning to serve. At the polling station, I carefully filled out my ballot, but as I handed it over, the poll worker frowned and pointed out a smudge on the envelope. “I’m sorry, but you’ll need to re-sign this so your vote counts,” she said gently. I glanced at the clock, anxiety prickling at my skin. The food drive was starting, and the sisters would be looking for me to help organize the donations. Yet, as a voter, I was expected to follow every instruction to ensure my ballot was valid. I felt torn—my heart tugged toward the shelter, but my conscience insisted I do this right. The weight of both roles pressed on me, and I stood frozen, pen in hand, caught between the needs of my community and the demands of my country.
